title: CSRF vulnerability allows disabling Gmail contacts link for user referrals
vulnerability_information:
##Summary:

#Hi team 

when user add ==Referrals== to his account use https://crm.na1.insightly.com/users/referrals he will get id to his linked account so when he try to disable the linked account in ==CONNECTED APPLICATION SETTINGS== in the end point https://crm.na1.insightly.com/users/usersettings ==request== contain the id will be send https://crm.na1.insightly.com/Users/GoogleDisable/2023554
The vulnerable endpoint allows an authenticated user to change the email address associated with their account and ==Remove it==(disableit) However, it does not sufficiently verify that requests were intentionally performed by the user (e.g. by checking the values of HTTP headers a).


#Step's
1-First  we need to account to confirm the issue account ==A== and ==B==
2-Go to https://crm.na1.insightly.com/users/referrals and add Google Referrals to both account's use two account's
3-Now the linked account will have two id not the same
4-From account ==A== Go to https://crm.na1.insightly.com/users/usersettingstry to disable the linked account   and capitsher the request use ==Burp proxy==
5- Generate  the POC use the Disable Request 
6-when open the link from account ==B== the bug will be exploite

#Proof-of-Concept (PoC)
This is the code used for the demonstration video attached to this report
```
<html>
  <!-- CSRF PoC - generated by Burp Suite Professional -->
  <body>
  <script>history.pushState('', '', '/')</script>
    <form action="https://crm.na1.insightly.com/Users/GoogleDisable/2026462">
      <input type="hidden" name="_pjax" value="#main" />
      <input type="submit" value="Submit request" />
    </form>
  </body>
</html>
```
when send the request the id will auto been change so victim linked account will be disabled

## Impact

An attacker can exploit this vulnerability in order to disable account linked or take over accounts by associating them with an address controlled by the attacker, then performing a password reset. In order for the attack to be successful, the target user account must be associated with an unconfirmed email address, and the target user must visit an attacker-controlled website while logged in.
